page.title: 19Housing.
page.content: The oldest houses in Tumble are Terraced, they were built very quickly and cheaply by the Mining Company who had opened the Great Mountain Colliery. The houses were built on either side of the main road and very close to the mine. These houses have now been modernised and bought by the occupiers. By 1910 there were 263 houses (adult population 1 389) and Tumble more or less was as it is today, except for the eight Council Estates and private homes that have been built since then and the Second World War. The majority of the houses are semi-detached, especially the council houses. Many of the council houses have been bought by the families who lived in them. Most of the privately built houses are detached bungalows and are owned by the occupiers.
